qas.question: Mrs. Dubose suffers from an addiction to what?
Who is the moral center of the novel?
The novel explores various forms of what trait?

context: The novel has been noted for its poignant exploration of different forms of <a2_0>courage<a2_0/>. Scout's impulsive inclination to fight students who insult <a1_0>Atticus<a1_0/> reflects her attempt to stand up for him and defend him. Atticus is the moral center of the novel, however, and he teaches Jem one of the most significant lessons of courage. In a statement that foreshadows Atticus' motivation for defending Tom Robinson and describes Mrs. Dubose, who is determined to break herself of a <a0_0>morphine<a0_0/> addiction, Atticus tells Jem that courage is "when you're licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you see it through no matter what".
